case_name: Dhawan Group v. Diwan Chaman Lal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 754 of 1957 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 754 of 1957. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against order dated September 29, 1954 of Deputy Custodian General in Revision Petition No. 321 R ADCG/53.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment, and order dated September 29, 1954, of the Deputy Custodian General, Evacuee Property, in Revision Petition No. 321 R ADCG/53.

facts.text: Additional Deputy Custodian-General order dated September 29, 1954 set aside order dated August 25, 1952 of Additional Custodian, Rural, Jullundur.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the order of the Additional Deputy Custodian-General of Evacuee Property, New Delhi, dated September 29, 1954, setting aside the order dated August 25, 1952

facts.text: Additional Custodian, Rural, Jullundur order dated August 25, 1952 confirmed Deputy Commissioner, Ambala order dated May 12, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: of the Additional Custodian, Rural, Jullundur, companyfirming that of the Deputy Commissioner, Ambala, dated May 12, 1951.

facts.text: Appellant Purshotam Lal Dhawan belongs to Dhawan Group of evacuees.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is preferred by Purshotam Lal Dhawan, a member of the Dhawan Group, against the said order.

facts.text: Diwan Chaman Lal (respondent No. 1) was a displaced person from West Pakistan owning considerable properties there.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant belongs to a group of evacuees which may for companyvenience be described as Dhawan Group. Diwan Chaman Lal, respondent No. 1, was a displaced person from West Pakistan where he owned companysiderable properties.

facts.text: On September 1, 1949, Diwan Chaman Lal allotted 152.9 acres of land in village Kharwan, Tehsil Jagadhri, District Ambala.

anchor.surface_text: On September 1, 1949, in lieu of land left behind in Pakistan, he was allotted 152.9 acres of land in village Kharwan in Tehsil Jagadhri, District Ambala.

facts.text: Dhawan Group members allotted different extents of land in village Kharwan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his group also owned large extents of properties in West Pakistan. Each one of that group was allotted different extents of land in the same village.

facts.text: Hari Chand filed application dated November 14, 1949 for re-allotment.

anchor.surface_text: Before possession was taken by the allottees, two persons, namely, Hari Chand and Khilla Ram, filed applications dated November 14, 1949, and November 11, 1949, respectively for re-allotment

facts.text: Khilla Ram filed application dated November 11, 1949 for re-allotment on ground of non-uniform soil quality.

anchor.surface_text: Before possession was taken by the allottees, two persons, namely, Hari Chand and Khilla Ram, filed applications dated November 14, 1949, and November 11, 1949, respectively for re-allotment on the ground that the soil of the village was number of uniform quality

facts.text: Additional Deputy Commissioner, Ambala recommended splitting land into four blocks, accepted by Director-General, Rural Rehabilitation on December 2, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Deputy Commissioner, Ambala, re- companymended the splitting of the land into four blocks and the said recommendation was accepted by the Director-General, Rural Rehabilitation, by his order dated December 2, 1949.

facts.text: Village Kharwan divided into four blocks and re-allotted.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the village was divided into four blocks and was re-allotted.

facts.text: Due to re-allotment, first respondent received land in different blocks and villages instead of entire allotment in Kharwan.

anchor.surface_text: On account of the re-allotment, the 1st respondent companyld number get his entire allotment in village Kharwan in one block and he was given instead land in different blocks and different villages.

facts.text: First respondent filed review application to Deputy Commissioner, Ambala on September 27, 1950 for restoration of original allotment.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order, the first respondent filed a review application before the Deputy Commissioner, Ambala, on September 27, 1950, praying for the restoration of his original allotment made on September 1, 1949.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner, Ambala rejected review application on May 12, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner, Ambala, rejected that application on May 12, 1951.

facts.text: First respondent preferred revision to Additional Custodian, dismissed on August 25, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the first respondent preferred a revision to the Additional Custodian, who dismissed the same on August 25, 1952.

facts.text: First respondent filed revision to Custodian-General on October 10, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The revision was filed on October 10, 1952.

facts.text: Additional Custodian order dated August 25, 1952 communicated to first respondent on September 11, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The said order was companymunicated to the first respondent on September 11, 1952.

facts.text: Dhawan Group impleaded as parties by order dated August 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: To that revision only the Custodian was made party but the appellant and the members of his group were subsequently made parties by an order of the Deputy Custodian-General dated August 25, 1953.

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General cancelled allotment to Dhawan Group excess area on September 29, 1954 and directed use for consolidation of first respondent's allotment.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Custodian-General cancelled the allotment made in favour of the Dhawan Group in respect of the excess area allotted to them and directed the land obtained by means of this cancellation to be utilised for the companysolidation of the allotment of the first respondent in village Kharwan.

facts.text: Appellant contended revision barred by time against Dhawan Group.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended before the Deputy Custodian-General that the revision petition was barred by time against the Dhawan Group, but the Deputy Custodian- General rejected that argument

facts.text: Deputy Custodian-General reports indicated Dhawan Group claims not verified, no parcha claims produced, claims not traceable, no allotment order forthcoming.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has rightly companytended that the Dhawan Group had numberverified claim for the allotment of this excess area and in spite of an opportunity afforded by me to them to produce the companyies of their Parcha Claim, they have failed to do so. The reports of the Land Claims Officer dated 7th August 1952

facts.text: Court holds factum of allotment to appellant was never questioned and disposes on basis that there was an allotment.

anchor.surface_text: These observation do number record a clear finding that there was numberallotment in favour of the appellant. Indeed the factum of allotment to the appellant was never questioned throughout the proceedings. In the circumstances, we must dispose of this appeal on the basis that there was an allotment in favour of the appellant.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment, and order dated September 29, 1954, of the Deputy Custodian General, Evacuee Property, in Revision Petition No. 321 R ADCG/53.

concepts.interpretation: Power of Custodian to cancel allotments.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14. (6) Notwithstanding anything contained in this rule, the Custodian of Evacuee Property in the State of Punjab shall not exercise the power of cancelling any allotment of rural evacuee property on a quasi-permanent basis, or varying the terms of any such allotment, except in the following circumstances ... Provided further nothing in this sub-rule shall apply to any application for revision, made under section 26 or section 27 of the Act, within the prescribed time, against an order passed by the lower authority on or before 22nd July, 1952.

concepts.interpretation: Limits Custodian's power to cancel quasi-permanent allotments except in specified cases; proviso lifts ban for timely revisions under ss.26/27 against pre-22 July 1952 orders.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the Deputy Custodian- General can set aside the allotment made on December 2, 1949. The question raised falls to be decided on the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder.

holdings.text: The revision was not barred by limitation in so far as the Dhawan Group was concerned

anchor.surface_text: The first question for consideration is whether-the revision was barred by limitation in so far as the Dhawan Group was concerned. Some of the relevant provisions regulating the power of revision of the Custodian-General may be noticed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 27 confers plenary revisional power at any time suo motu or on application; Rule 31(5) 'ordinarily within 60 days' is directory rule of guidance, not mandatory limitation; harmonious construction avoids ultra vires; contrast with rigid appeal limits; S.5 Limitation Act inapplicable; discretion exercised reasonably after hearing parties.

holdings.text: Rule 31(5) does not impose a rigid period of limitation but is only a rule of guidance

anchor.surface_text: Rule 31. (5) Any petition for revision when made to the Custodian-General shall ordinarily be made within sixty days of the date of the order sought to be revised. The petition shall be presented in person or through a legal practitioner or a recognized agent or may be sent by registered post.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Ordinarily' indicates discretion; must be read consistent with unlimited power in S.27; rigid limit would be ultra vires; differs from mandatory appeal periods in Rule 31(1).

holdings.text: Principle underlying S.5 Limitation Act does not apply to revision under S.27

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the principle underlying s. 5 of the Limitation Act applies to a petition for revision under s. 27 of the Act has no force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No limitation period prescribed for S.27 revisions, unlike appeals where condonation applies.

holdings.text: Custodian-General had power to cancel the quasi-permanent allotment made before July 22, 1952

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the Deputy Custodian- General can set aside the allotment made on December 2, 1949. The question raised falls to be decided on the relevant provisions of the Act and the rules made thereunder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to Rule 14(6) excepts revisions under S.26/27 within prescribed time against pre-July 22, 1952 orders; prescribed time under Rule 31(5) is ordinarily 60 days but extendable in discretion; S.11 and S.27 enable cancellation if illegal/improper.

holdings.text: There was an allotment in favour of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: These observation do not record a clear finding that there was no allotment in favour of the appellant. Indeed the factum of allotment to the appellant was never questioned throughout the proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DCG observations on unverified claims/no parcha/no order do not negate factum of allotment; issue never disputed in proceedings; dispose on that basis.

holdings.text: Custodian-General complied with natural justice requirements

anchor.surface_text: The Dhawan Group was made party at the subsequent stage as the Custodian-General rightly thought that any order he would make in favour of the appellant might prejudice the Dhawan Group. After giving them a reasonable opportunity

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impleaded parties, issued notices, gave reasonable opportunity of being heard per proviso to S.27.
